summary: Louis Stokes is identified as an authorizing official on payroll authorization forms for the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA). His signature appears on documents related to the employment and salary adjustments of various HSCA staff members. The documents span from 1976 to 1978, indicating his active role during the committee's operational period. The documents primarily focus on administrative matters such as payroll, employment terms, and compliance with regulations, rather than investigative findings or substantive aspects of the JFK assassination or the Martin Luther King Jr. assassination. His role appears to be largely administrative, approving personnel actions within the HSCA.
significance: Louis Stokes' significance in the JFK assassination context, based on these documents, is primarily related to his administrative role within the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA). He authorized payroll and personnel actions for HSCA staff, indicating his involvement in the operational management of the committee. While the documents do not reveal his direct involvement in the investigation itself, his authorization of staff appointments and payments suggests he played a part in ensuring the committee's functioning.
